heading: learning shrinks your brain
subheading: learning will shrink your brain in later life, new research has found. but don't worry, a shrunken brain won't affect your memory or your likelihood of developing dementia. by leander kahney.
author: wired news report
text: education can shrink your brain, according to recently published research. researchers at henry ford health system found that the higher the level of education, the more your brain is likely to shrink as you get older.however, while better-educated seniors have smaller brains, they are less likely to suffer from memory loss and age-related impairments or dementias."our research shows that education exerts a protective effect," said c. edward coffey, chair of henry ford's department of psychiatry and the study's principal investigator, in a statement.the researchers used magnetic resonance imaging (mri) to measure the cerebrospinal fluid in the brains in about 300 seniors aged between 66 to 90.as the brain shrinks, the space is filled with cerebrospinal fluid.the study found that each year of education leads to approximately one third of a teaspoon (1.77 ml) more cerebrospinal fluid. seniors with 16 years of education had approximately 10 percent more cerebrospinal fluid (and correspondingly smaller brains) than those with only four years of education.the study is published in the july issue of neurology.
